bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Sebastian Lorente to Wenceslao Pareja, June 15, 1925 [Enclosed in C0309004]

div1.p: Lorente believes the restrictions on commerce between Peru and Ecuador were based on unfounded rumors of yellow fever in northern Peru, and that such rumors should be substantiated before being acted upon in future.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Sebastian Lorente to Wenceslao Pareja, June 15, 1925 [Enclosed in C0309004]
div1.opener:
1
Translated from the Spanish, HRM
7-24-25
HRM
MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR (FOMENTO)
Department of Public Health
Lima,
June 15, 1925.
My dear colleague:
div1.p:
I take pleasure in acknowledging receipt of your cablegram,
dated this day, which reads as follows:

“Health Director -Lima- Pardon failure to reply your
cablegram, waited confirmation from our representative Piura, Dr.
Sayago, who to-day communicates confirmation absence yellow fever north
Peru; we immediately suspended restrictions taken as precaution never
too excessive in such grave danger. Pareja- Health Director.”

I am very much pleased to know that Dr. Sayago, commissioned
by your Department to study the sanitary conditions of the Department of
Piura, has confirmed the absence of yellow fever in northern Peru and that
as a result of this confirmation your Department has proceeded to lift the
restrictions imposed on the traffic and commerce between Peruvian ports and
Guayaquil-restrictions which you issued when you credited the rumor that
yellow fever was present in this zone of the Peruvian coast.

Now that the unpleasant situation created by these restrictions
has passed, please allow me, my distinguished colleague, to state that this
Department of Health appreciates the fact that there can be no exaggerated
precautions in defending a country against the importation of such an
epidemic disease as is yellow fever and that, therefore, the quarantine
measures imposed on the traffic are justified when there is real danger; but
this Department of Health also appreciates the fact that when this danger
exists only as a rumor, propagated by ill-intentioned persons, it is necessary
to investigate its reality, before dictating defensive measures causing very serious harm.

Peru as well as Ecuador is a signatory of the Sanitary
Convention of Washington, and it, as you know, imposes on the signatory
countries the obligation of communicating to the rest the appearance in
its territory of the first confirmed case of yellow fever. Peru, which
respects international faith and complies with the convenants in force, has
not communicated the presence of a case of yellow fever on this occasion,
as it has done on previous occasions, because this case has not been produced.
It, therefore, had the right to suppose that since it had not officially
communicated the presence of this disease in its territory, no credit would
have been given in the neighboring countries to the more or less unfounded
rumors which may have been produced; that, if these rumors succeeded in
arousing alarm, the health administrations of these countries would have
asked for official data through their representatives in Peru; and that the
official statement of your public health service published as in this case
not only in the local periodicals, available to the diplomatic and consular
representatives residing in Lima, but directly, in what might be called a
note of protest to the cablegram I sent you, denying the existence of yellow
fever in Peru, would suffice to calm your health administration and avoid the
quarantine measures which were imposed in Ecuador on everything that came from
Peru. (The language contradicts the evident meaning - translator)

In addition, the rumor of the existence of yellow fever in Piura
which alarmed the Ecuadorian sanitary authorities lacked sufficient foundation
to be given credit. You very well know, my distinguished colleague, that
yellow fever does not appear in immune localities, except when the germ is
imported from other infected localities. Since, therefore, there is no yellow
fever at the present time in the countries on the west coast of South America,
how could yellow fever have originated in Piura? The rumor was, therefore,
a priori, unworthy of belief.

Hoping that this communication is the starting point of
closer relations between the Departments of Health in your care and mine
in benefit of reciprocal interests, I remain,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (signed) SEBASTIAN LORENTE Director of Health
Dr. Wenceslao Pareja
Director of Public Health
Guayaquil
